prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for leaving my daughter's friend at the park?
A few days ago I was coming home from work. My daughter wanted to be picked up so I drove over to the park (where she was at). 

When I got there, there was this other who was my daughter's friend. She apparently needed a ride home. I declined her. 

After that, I drove my daughter home. Another important detail is that it was around six a clock at the time I picked my daughter up.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see here. The user is asking if the person who wrote this situation is in the wrong for leaving their daughter's friend at the park.

So the scenario is: The author was picking up their daughter from the park after work. When they got there, the daughter's friend was also there and wanted a ride home. The author declined and took their daughter home. It was around 6 PM. 

First, I need to figure out if the author had any obligation to give the friend a ride. The parent's main responsibility is their own child. The friend's parent might be responsible for getting their child home. Unless the parent had prior knowledge or agreed to pick up the friend, they aren't obligated. 

Was there any expectation set before? The question doesn't mention if the parent had agreed to take the friend. If the friend's parent expected this, maybe the author didn't communicate properly. But from the given info, the author wasn't told beforehand. 

Also, the time was 6 PM. If it's after school hours, maybe the friend was supposed to be picked up earlier. If the friend stayed past their usual time, maybe the friend's parent is at fault for not picking up on time. 

The author's primary duty is their own child. Unless there's a prior agreement or a clear expectation, it's not their responsibility. Declining the ride isn't wrong. So the answer is B, the author isn't in the wrong.
